Vote - Accept-Straight-to-Finalization - TEXT: adjust spaces after <: markup throughout; insert lost.?lin on both sides of fr. 1, on top of fr. 2, and on bottom of fr. 3; delete |ed| markup in i.1, replace scribal middot with actual middot, and accent τῶι; delete |ed| markup in i.2; insert a comma after ναυπηγή|σωνται in i.3; delete |ed| markup in i.4; insert a raised dot after αὐτῶν in i.4; insert a raised dot after χρέωνται in i.5; change scribal middot in i.8 to high-punctus; delete |ed| markup in i.8; insert scribal middot after -ται in i.11, encode scribal diairesis on ἱστῶι in i.11 and correct d to delta; insert comma after χρέωνται in i.12; insert period at end of i.13; encode [Α]ἴ̣[γ]υ̣[πτος,] in ii.14; move enclitic accent in ii.14; add accent to Ἀρχάνδρου in ii.18; remove |ed| markup in ii.18-19 and note the misplaced scribal middot in a commentary note (add a period after Ἀχαιοῦ); remove |ed| markup in ii.21; change scribal middot at end of ii.21 to high-punctus; add enclitic accent to Αἰγύπτιόν γε in ii.22; change scribal middot in ii.23 to high-punctus; add scribal diairesis in ii.25; insert comma after Sesotrin in iii.26; add accent to παίδων in iii.27; change scribal middot in iii.29 to high-punctus; remove extra space before square bracket in iii.32; remove |ed| markup in iii.33; insert comma after ἀδελ|φεόν in iii.34; add .? to square brackets at end of iii.34. COMMENTARY: remove comment for i.4, i.8, correct spelling of Lloyd in i.13, remove comment in ii.22. META: remove volume number from biblio 95015; add #11 to biblio 4392; add biblio 37418 (page 147) as a study; add biblio 9676 (page 176) as a study; add biblio 11526 as a study; add biblio 68526 as a study; add Liège to printed images; update display name to P. Ryl. 1 55; passage details are Hdt 2.96.2, 2.98.2-99., 2.107.2-108; Herodotus CWKB numbers (915, 2691)

Submit - Originally submitted to litpap.info 2017.12.10 by David Wheeler. Submission has been transferred to papyri.info. Submission notes were: "completed as an assignment for T. Hickey"

div.p: These fragments are carefully written in a handsome upright uncial script, probably from the second century (which bears a strong resemblance to the hand of the famous London Bacchylides papyrus, but the formation of the omega is different), though a corrector’s hand has been noted at lines 20 and 34. The fragments appear to have been deliberately cut due to the clear, straight edges. The top margin of Frag 3 is deep, which is consistent with the fine hand, and the verso of each fragment has been left blank. Frag 1 has paragraphoi, which appear to be from the original scribe, however they are conspicuously absent from Frag 3.

div.ab:
α ξύλα· ἐπεὰν δὲ τῶι τρό
πωι τούτωι ναυπηγή
σωνται, ζυγὰ ἐπιπολῆς
τίνουσι αὐτῶν· νομεῦ
σι δὲ οὐδὲν χρέωνται· ἔ
σωθεν δὲ τὰς ἁρμονίας
ἐν ὦν ἐπάκτωσαν τῆι
βύβλωι πηδάλιον δὲ ἓν
ποιεόνταιποιεῦνται καὶ τοῦτο δι
ὰ τῆς τρόπιος διαβύνε
ται ἱστῶι δὲ ἀκανθίνωι
χρέωνται, ἱστίοισι δὲ
βυβλίνοισι.

ὑπό Πέρσηισί ἐστι Αἴγυπτος,
ἡ δὲ ἑτέρη δοκέει μοι πό
λιςπόλις δοκέει μοι τὸ οὔνομα σχεῖνἔχειν ἀπὸ
τοῦ Δαναοῦ γαμβροῦ Ἀρ
χάνδρου τοῦ Φθίου τοῦ
Ἀχαιοῦ. καλέεται γὰρ δὴ
Ἀρχάνδρου πόλις εἴη δ’ ἂν
καὶ ἄλλος τις Ἄρχανδρος
οὐ μέντοι Αἰγύπτιόν γεγε Αἰγύπτιον
τὸ οὔνομα μέχρι μὲν
τούτου ὄψις τε ἐμὴ καὶ
γνώμη καὶ ἱστορίηι

ποιῆσαι τὸν Σέσωστριν,
καὶ δύο μὲν τῶν παίδων
κατακαῆναι τρόπωι τοι
ούτωι τοὺς δὲ λοιποὺς ἀ
ποσωθῆναι ἅμα τῶι πα
τρί νοστήσας δὲ ὁ Σέσω
στρις ἐς τὴν Αἴγυπτον
καὶ τισάμενος τεισάμενος τὸν ἀδελ
φεόν, τῶι μὲν ὁμίλωι

item.p: D supports this reading of the papyrus, and it is what Wilson thinks is the most likely choice. However, little remains of the first letter of this word on the papyrus, and so it is at least possible that ζυγὰ could be the correct reading. A middot as been added after the alpha as the most likely reconstruction due to the paragraphos and the space beteen the alpha and epsilon.
Lloyd notes that though no pharaonic source attests to the use of papyrus for sails, it is nevertheless still possible.
Correction is in a different hand

Herodotus' Sesostris is probably to be identified with one of the three kings of the twelfth dynasty that bear the name Senusret. This is also the Sesostris mentioned by Manetho (Fr. 34-36) as being the third king of the 12th dynasty, for whom he records a 48 year reign, and Diodorus Siculus’ Sesoösis (I.53). Though Sesostris should be read as a legendary figure by Herodotus’ time, based on the length of his reign and that he appears to have been succeeded by Amenemhet III, the most likely conclusion is that Herodotus’ Sesostris is a combination of Senusret II and III. Manetho and Diodorus provide a similar picture of Sesostris the conqueror, and Diodorus also tells the story about his brother and the fire (I. 57.6), albeit with a different ending.
It is possible this stop is a later addition

Manetho makes no mention of this story, and Diodorus' version (I. 57.7) ends differently: ὁ δὲ Σεσόωσις ἀμφοτέρας τὰς χεῖρας ἀνατείνας καὶ ὑπὲρ τῆς σωτηρίας τῶν τε παίδων καὶ τῆς γυναικὸς τοῖς θεοῖς εὐξάμενος διεξέπεσε διὰ τῆς φλογός.
Corrections are in a different hand

div.p: Letters are widely spaced, occasionally finished off with small apices. Stops in both the high and middle positions occur, and some of these may be due to the original scribe.
